Real-time simulation for a virtual reality-based MIG welding training system
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • SI: Manufacturing and Construction
  • Published: 14 September 2010

Real-time simulation for a virtual reality-based MIG welding training system

  • Terrence L. Chambers1,
  • Amit Aglawe1,
  • Dirk Reiners2,
  • Steven White2,
  • Christoph W. Borst2,
  • Mores Prachyabrued2 &
  • Abhishek Bajpayee1 

Virtual Reality volume 16, pages45–55(2012)Cite this article

  • 718 Accesses

  • 8 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

This paper describes a real-time welding simulation method for use in a desktop virtual reality simulated Metal Inert Gas welding training system. The simulation defines the shape of the weld bead, the depth of penetration, and the temperature distribution in the workpiece, based on inputs from the motion-tracking system that tracks the position of the welding gun as a function of time. A finite difference method is used to calculate the temperature distribution, including the width of the weld bead and the depth of penetration. The shape of the weld bead is then calculated at each time step by assuming a semi-spherical volume, based on the width of the weld bead, the welding speed, and the wire feed rate. The real-time performance of the system is examined, and results from the real-time simulation are compared to physical tests and are found to have very good correlation for welding speeds up to 1,000 mm/min.

Introduction

Gas metal arc welding (GMAW), also known as metal inert gas (MIG) welding, is a very common industrial metal-joining process. The training of competent MIG welders is a very time and resource-intensive process, however. Although the basic concepts can be learned from books and lectures, much of the art of MIG welding involves developing (through a great deal of practice) the manual dexterity, hand-eye coordination, and fine motor control skills necessary to consistently produce a proper weld. This practice is costly in terms of the welding machine itself, in addition to the gas, wire, and metal workpieces that are expended in the welding process. In addition, the real-world welding process is one in which the visual field is so obscured that it is very difficult for the beginning student to tell the difference, while welding, between the motions of the welding gun that produce a good weld and those that produce a bad weld. As a result, the student must usually complete a short weld bead and then call the instructor over to critique the work. By that time, the muscle memory of the hand and arm motions that produced the weld (whether good or bad) may have been forgotten.

The goal for this project was to build an inexpensive desktop virtual reality-based training system for simulated metal inert gas welding (called sMIG) that would provide interactive 3D visual and stereo auditory feedback to the student with regard to the weld being created in real time. The intent was that the student could then develop the manual dexterity necessary for MIG welding in the virtual world before beginning to train on a real MIG welding system. The benefits of such a system would be (1) better training for the students due to the real-time feedback provided by the virtual system and (2) a savings of cost in terms of valuable and limited instructor time, as well as a savings in consumable supplies and materials.

The complete sMIG system is described in White et al. (2010), but a brief introduction is given here. Figure 1 below illustrates the system components. The VR peripherals used for the simulation are three OptiTrack FLEX:V100 cameras for tracking the motion of the user, a Samsung SyncMaster™ 2233RZ 120 Hz 3D LCD monitor for the display of both the workpiece and the weld bead, and reflective optical tracking markers mounted on a standard MIG welding gun and on a standard welding helmet (with the lens removed) to determine the gun position and the head position of the user. The OptiTrack FLEX:V100 camera is an integrated image capture processing unit that can capture 100 frames per second. The Samsung 3D LCD monitor has the capability to support both 3D and 2D realizations. When used in 3D mode, the 120 Hz display is split into two stereo displays, one for each eye, that are alternately displayed at a rate of 60 Hz. The user wears nVidia GeForce3D active glasses underneath the welding helmet. The active glasses are synchronized to the display so that the simulated workpiece and the simulated weld bead are perceived as having height, as well as length and width. Standard PC speakers provide auditory feedback based on the material of the workpiece and other welding parameters such as voltage and the height of the welding gun above the workpiece.

Figure 2 below shows how the simulation of the weld bead can accommodate a curved path and varying speeds of the welding gun. The simulation calculates the temperature distribution in the plate (Fig. 2—left pane) and displays the weld bead as it is being created by the user in real time. The simulation can respond to arbitrary motions of the student’s welding gun, which is one of the unique features of this system.

The sMIG system provides feedback not available in real life to help the novice welder find the right gap between the workpiece and gun, as well as the correct welding speed. To aid students during training, a set of guidelines and circles that are proportional to the gun speed and height are drawn near the gun’s position. A secondary set is drawn at a constant size representing the ideal height and speed. When the two lines meet within an adjustable tolerance, they are drawn as a single yellow line meaning that the user is operating at the proper height and velocity. If the user actually touches the workpiece, an audible warning and a flash of light are produced. To avoid damage to the computer monitor, the screen is protected by an acrylic plate.

This paper describes the portion of the sMIG project that deals with the real-time numerical simulation of the temperature distribution in the plate and the shape of the weld bead itself. First, prior efforts to simulate the weld bead in real time will be described, followed by a description of the method used in this project. The various simplifying assumptions that were used to reduce the computational cost and improve real-time performance will also be described. The resulting real-time performance is described, and finally, the results of the real-time simulation will be compared to experimental weld samples and discussed.

Prior work

A great deal of work has already been done to model the welding process using finite element analysis (FEA). SYSWELD and WELDSIM are two examples of finite element software packages developed specifically to model the welding process. High-fidelity models have been developed using both dedicated FEA packages, such as SYSWELD, and other general purpose FEA packages, such as Ansys. These high-fidelity models often take into account every conceivable aspect of the welding process, including the heat affected zone, residual stresses, distortion of the weldment, and cracking. Examples of recent applications of this method include Zeng et al. (2009), Wu et al. (2007), and Lee et al. (2004). The results of these high-fidelity finite element models are useful in extending our understanding (and thereby controlling) the welding process itself. On the other hand, high-fidelity models are inherently computationally expensive (requiring several minutes or even sometimes multiple hours to run) and are not fast enough for interactive real-time use, which requires the simulation to be completed several times per second. In addition, they typically assume a pre-assigned path of the welding gun and are inappropriate for a real-time interactive welding simulator that seeks to track arbitrary motions of a student user. This work does not attempt to improve on current high-fidelity modeling techniques nor does it intend to extend our understanding of the welding process itself. As a result, we will not focus our discussion on FEA welding simulation techniques; however, they may be useful for other purposes. Instead, we will focus on prior attempts to develop interactive, real-time welding simulations, especially those with virtual reality aspects.

There are several welding simulations that allow a user to completely interact with the simulated environment, which includes basic operations such as selecting a workpiece and mounting it on the work table. One such immersive and interactive welding simulation was developed by (Mavrikios et al. 2006), which allows the user to decide on the type of welding (TIG/MIG) and welding parameters such as feed rate of wire, wire material, and the shield gas. This simulation did not taken into consideration the temperature distribution in the workpiece. The shape of the weld bead was simulated using an ellipsoidal shape created in real time in front of the welding tip and on the metal sheets.

Another technique for estimating the weld bead shape is to use artificial neural networks (ANN). This approach is based on data that define the relationship between the welding parameters (inputs) and weld profile (output) (Porter et al. 2006). Welding parameters are mapped to the weld dimensions through internal representation of back-propagation networks (BPN), a branch of ANN (Chan et al. 1999). Physical characteristic data acquired from sample welds are used to build or to train the neural network system. Some of the input parameters that are considered in the sample welds are work angle, travel angle, contact tip-to-work distance, current, voltage, and wire feed speed. Different settings of these parameters are used to determine outputs such as weld penetration, bead size, and bead shape. The numerical model based on these parameters helps to predict the shape of weld bead, which is then validated with experimental welds. Figure 3 shows a schematic of the BPN used for predicting the weld bead dimensions. The shape of the bead can be defined by the number of points that represent the weld bead geometry as described by Kim et al. (1999).

Chan et al. (1999) developed an ANN model of the weld bead shape. They performed 96 bead-on-plate welds and found that there is no simple shape that explains the shape of the weld bead. An ellipse (as later used by Mavrikios et al. 2006) tends to overestimate the size of the weld bead, and a parabola tends to slightly underestimate the size. However, the parabola was found to match the shape of weld bead most closely and was therefore adopted for their work. It was assumed that the weld bead was formed by extruding the 2D parabolic cross-section at a constant speed along the straight line formed by the weld joint. An arbitrary path could not be accommodated by this simulation.

Another ANN-based virtual welding simulation developed by Fast et al. (2004) to simulate gas metal arc welding (GMAW) is now available as a commercial package called SimWelder and is available from VRsim, Inc. This simulator consists of a real welding torch mounted on a haptic device with 6 DOF. The input parameters for simulating welding are obtained by tracking the position and speed of the welding gun during the welding process similar to the later work of Porter et al. (2006). However, in this simulation, the path of the welding gun is fixed to a straight line and the calculated temperature distribution is not in real time. The original cost for a single seat of SimWelder was $100,000 USD, but this has since been reduced to the neighborhood of $40,000. An educational version (SimWelder Ed) is available for $25,500.

The weld pool geometry is also affected by the volume and temperature of molten metal from the filler wire, and these effects have been studied by several researchers. The melting of the electrode causes rapid formation of drops that are transferred into the pool formed at the joint between the workpieces (Kumar and Bhaduri 1994). The wire electrode is melted and the molten metal is transferred to the workpiece (Kim and Basu 1998). The size of the drop formed at the tip of welding gun depends on the current (Jones et al. 1997). In GMAW, the metal transfer process mainly involves the movement of molten metal from the welding gun tip to the workpiece. This process is governed by several phenomena such as gravitational, surface tension, and electromagnetic forces (as described by Wang et al. 2003).

Other assumptions that have been made include the following: the input velocity of molten metal is assumed to be the same as the wire feed rate (Wang et al. 2003); the flow is incompressible, laminar, and axisymmetric, hence the calculation domain is taken as one side of the centerline (Kim and Basu 1998; Wang et al. 2003; Fan and Kovacevic 1998; Zhang et al. 2004); there is no creep at solid boundaries (Wang et al. 2003); and all the physical properties of liquid and solid metals are constant independent of temperature (Kim and Basu 1998). The process of determining the shape of the weld bead is governed by arc pressure, fluid dynamics, and droplet impact. The geometry of the weld shape is based on the actual weld wire deposited (Davoud and Deng 2003). Under ideal conditions, the volume of the weld reinforcement formed is a function of welding speed and feed rate of the wire. The parabolic cross-sectional area of the weld reinforcement can be calculated by dividing the melted amount of wire per unit time by the welding speed (Wu et al. 2007).

Existing systems have so far either modeled the weld bead in a sophisticated way that is too computationally expensive for real-time use (FEA-based systems) or used simplified models (such as ANNs) to improve the performance at the expense of simulation fidelity. In addition, many systems make the assumption of constant gun speed and direction, which render those methods unsuitable for a real-time interactive training system.

The sMIG system described in this paper, in Aglawe (2008), and in White et al. (2010) is most similar to the SimWelder system described by Fast et al. (2004). The sMIG system is different from the SimWelder system, however, in that, it seeks to find a lower-cost solution ($5,500 USD) by using a unique combination of off-the-shelf VR components and by simulating the temperature distribution in the plate, the shape of the weld bead, and the depth of penetration in real time by using the finite difference approach (as described below) rather than the ANN method. The sMIG system can accommodate an arbitrary path and varying speeds of the welding gun.

Methods

This section describes the numerical welding simulation method used by sMIG to predict the shape of the weld bead and the depth of penetration in real time by taking into consideration the welding speed, wire feed rate, and the welding gun position. In this simulation, the finite difference method is used to calculate the temperature distribution in the workpiece. The depth of penetration and the width of the weld bead are determined based on the temperature distribution. A three-dimensional parabolic shape is assumed for the weld bead, and the volume of the bead deposited per unit time is calculated based on the previously calculated width of the bead, the wire feed rate, and the gun velocity. The goal was to find a simulation technique that would strike a useful balance between accuracy in the prediction of the weld bead shape and computational cost of the simulation, so that the simulation could be used in a real-time interactive MIG welding training system. The target simulation time was to be less than 100 ms.

Calculation of temperature distribution

The workpiece considered for this simulation is a 10 cm × 10 cm metal plate with 2 cm thickness. The current version uses aluminum, but the technique is equally applicable to steel and other metallic materials. The workpiece is represented as a three-dimensional mesh (or lattice) with 100 nodes along the x- and y-axes and 20 nodes along the z-axis. Each of these nodes is identified by x, y, and z coordinates. The origin is set to the bottom-left of the top surface of the plate so that at the start of the welding process, all surface nodes have the z coordinate set to zero.

The motion-tracking system captures data that indicate the current position of the welding gun on the plate at each time step. Based on the current position and the speed of the welding gun, the shape of the weld bead and the temperature distribution are calculated. The finite difference method is used to calculate the temperature distribution in the plate. For this application, the transient heat transfer problem is approximated by partially converging the steady-state problem at each time step.

The derivation of the relevant heat transfer equations is adapted from the finite difference technique described by Patankar (1980). For the steady-state case with no heat addition, the temperature distribution in the plate is given by the Laplace equation:

$$ {\frac{{\partial^{2} T}}{{\partial X^{2} }}} + {\frac{{\partial^{2} T}}{{\partial Y^{2} }}} + {\frac{{\partial^{2} T}}{{\partial Z^{2} }}} = 0 $$
(1)

Obviously, heat is added to the plate by the welding gun, but this is accounted for in another manner described below. In this equation, T is the temperature and X, Y, and Z represent the coordinate directions. The plate is discretized as shown in Fig. 4.

A central difference second derivative approximation can be derived as shown below:

$$ {\frac{{\partial^{2} T}}{{\partial X^{2} }}} \cong {\frac{{T_{i + 1,j,k} - 2T_{i,j,k} + T_{i - 1,j,k} }}{{\Updelta X^{2} }}}, $$
(2)
$$ {\frac{{\partial^{2} T}}{{\partial Y^{2} }}} \cong {\frac{{T_{i,j + 1,k} - 2T_{i,j,k} + T_{i,j - 1,k} }}{{\Updelta Y^{2} }}}, $$
(3)
$$ {\frac{{\partial^{2} T}}{{\partial Z^{2} }}} \cong {\frac{{T_{i,j,k + 1} - 2T_{i,j,k} + T_{i,j,k - 1} }}{{\Updelta Z^{2} }}}, $$
(4)

where i, j, and k represent the coordinates of the node in the X, Y, and Z directions. Substituting the second derivative approximations into the Laplace equation, we get:

$$ {\frac{{T_{i + 1,j,k} - 2T_{i,j,k} + T_{i - 1,j,k} }}{{\Updelta X^{2} }}} + {\frac{{T_{i,j + 1,k} - 2T_{i,j,k} + T_{i,j - 1,k} }}{{\Updelta Y^{2} }}} + {\frac{{T_{i,j,k + 1} - 2T_{i,j,k} + T_{i,j,k - 1} }}{{\Updelta Z^{2} }}} = 0 $$
(5)

If ΔX = ΔY = ΔZ, then Eq. 2 reduces to:

$$ T_{i + 1,j,k} + T_{i - 1,j,k} + T_{i,j + 1,k} + T_{i,j - 1,k} + T_{i,j,k + 1} + T_{i,j,k - 1} - 6T_{i,j,k} = 0. $$
(6)

This equation can be written for each node in the plate. This yields a system of simultaneous linear equations that can be solved for all Ts for the known boundary conditions. For simplicity, this simulation assumes an adiabatic boundary condition to calculate the temperature distribution along the plate. The loss of energy to the atmosphere from the edge of the plate is considered to be insignificant and hence assumed to be zero. For the calculation of the temperature of the surface nodes (either top or bottom), it is assumed that the temperature of these nodes is affected only by the inside nodes. For example, the temperature of the top surface nodes will be affected by the surrounding five nodes, where as the temperature of the inside node is affected by the surrounding six nodes. This ignores the heat conducted to the work table through the bottom of the plate and the heat radiated to the environment from the top of the plate. Given the fact that during the actual welding process, the heat being transferred to the plate by the welding gun is always significantly larger than the heat being transferred away due to all causes, these cooling effects were deliberately ignored in an effort to produce a simulation that could be performed in real time.

The Gauss–Seidel method is used to solve the resulting system of simultaneous linear equations. In this method, we solve each equation in the system of equations for one variable in terms of all others, and then iterate. In this case, we re-write the equations as:

$$ T_{i,j,k} = {\frac{{T_{i + 1,j,k} + T_{i - 1,j,k} + T_{i,j + 1,k} + T_{i,j - 1,k} + T_{i,j,k + 1} + T_{i,j,k - 1} }}{6}} $$
(7)

Sometimes the Gauss–Seidel method tends to diverge, and this can be controlled by using under-relaxation as shown Eqs. 8 and 9 below.

$$ T_{\text{temp}} = {\frac{{T_{i + 1,j,k} + T_{i - 1,j,k} + T_{i,j + 1,k} + T_{i,j - 1,k} + T_{i,j,k + 1} + T_{i,j,k - 1} }}{6}}, $$
(8)
$$ T_{i,j,k} = \lambda T_{\text{temp}} + (1 - \lambda )T_{i,j,k} , $$
(9)

where λ is the relaxation factor. A relaxation factor value of 0.8 was found to give good convergence for this problem.

For this simulation, we did not attempt to converge the system of equations completely at each time step, which would have been too computationally expensive, so instead we simply performed eight iterations of the Gauss–Seidel method, which resulted in approximately a 90% convergence at each time step.

The motion tracker provides the position of the welding gun at each time step, and this position is mapped to a particular node in the grid. The temperature of that node is considered to be at the fixed input temperature imparted by the plasma arc of the welding gun. Arc temperatures for MIG welding vary from 6,000 to 8,000°C (Dorzin 2003). When simulating welding on aluminum, a fixed value of 6,500°C was empirically determined to give good results for this simulation technique. This known nodal temperature was used to solve the above system of simultaneous equations. This gives the temperature of each node in the plate at every time step. The number of nodes in the Z direction that exceed the melting temperature of aluminum, which is taken as 660°C (ETB 2005), determines the depth of penetration, and in a similar manner, the surface nodes that exceed the melting temperature determine the width of the weld bead, w. The width of the weld bead, w, is used as the primary input to determine the shape of the weld bead above the plate, as described below.

Shape of the weld bead

Chan et al. (1999) have shown that the cross-section of the weld bead is approximately parabolic. However, during the welding process, only the surface of the weld bead is visible and not the longitudinal cross-section. In this simulation, the shape of the weld bead is assumed to be parabolic as in Chan, but now the parabola is revolved around the y-axis, which produces a hemi-spherical shape. This simulation assumes that the volume of the feed wire deposited is equal to the volume of parabolic section revolved around the y-axis. The width of the parabola “w” is obtained from the temperature distribution simulation described earlier. The parabolic cross-section is calculated based on the following derivation (Fig. 5):

The second-order equation for the height of the parabola as a function of the x-distance from the location of the welding gun is shown in Eq. 10 below, where h is the maximum height of the weld bead and a is a constant to be determined.

$$ y = - ax^{2} + h $$
(10)

We can solve this equation for x:

$$ x = \sqrt {{\frac{h - y}{a}}} $$
(11)

At y = 0,

$$ x = \sqrt {\frac{h}{a}} = \frac{w}{2} $$
(12)

where w is the width of the weld bead.

Solving for a yields:

$$ a = {\frac{h}{{\left( {\frac{w}{2}} \right)^{2} }}}, $$
(13)

and

$$ a = {\frac{4h}{{w^{2} }}}. $$
(14)

We can find the volume of the weld, V weld, under the parabola by assuming a horizontal disk of infinitesimal thickness dy and integrating from the surface of the plate to the total height.

$$ V_{\text{weld}} = \int\limits_{0}^{h} {A_{\text{disk}} {\text{d}}y} = \int\limits_{0}^{h} {\pi x^{2} {\text{d}}y} = \pi\int\limits_{{0}}^{h} {\left( {{\frac{h - y}{a}}} \right){\text{d}}y = {\frac{{\pi h^{2} }}{a}}} $$
(15)

From Eqs. 14 and 15,

$$ V_{\text{weld}} = {\frac{{\pi \,hw^{2} }}{4}} $$
(16)

We assume that the volume of the wire, V wire, that is added to the weld bead during one time step, Δt, can be calculated from the diameter of the wire, d w , and the wire feed rate, f, as shown below.

$$ V_{\text{wire}} = {\frac{{\pi \,d_{w}^{2} }}{4}}f\,\Updelta t $$
(17)

By equating the volume of the weld bead and the volume of the wire, we get an expression for the maximum height of the weld bead, h, based only on the given values of wire diameter, d w , the wire federate, f, the time step, Δt, and the width of the weld bead, w, obtained by the calculation of the 3D temperature distribution described above.

$$ h = {\frac{{d_{w}^{2} f\,\Updelta t}}{{w^{2} }}} $$
(18)

By substituting the value of h into Eq. 14, we get:

$$ a = {\frac{{4d_{w}^{2} f\,\Updelta t}}{{w^{4} }}} $$
(19)

By substituting the value of a from Eq. 19 and the value of h from Eq. 18 into Eq. 10, we get an expression for the height of the weld bead, y, as a function of x and the width of the weld bead, w.

$$ y = - \left( {{\frac{{4d_{w}^{2} f\,\Updelta t}}{{w^{4} }}}} \right)x^{2} + \left( {{\frac{{d_{w}^{2} f\,\Updelta t}}{{w^{2} }}}} \right). $$
(20)

The origin of the revolved parabola is considered to be the position of the gun and using Eq. 19, the height of each node is calculated based on its distance from the location of the gun.

Sample welds

Actual MIG welding operations were performed to study the shape of the weld bead and the depth of penetration. An aluminum plate was used as a base material for these sample welds. Twenty-seven total sample welding operations were performed. Aluminum wire with diameter 0.045 mm was used as filler material. The feed rate of the wire was set to 214 mm/s in all cases. Three sample welds were obtained for average welding speeds of 156.6, 199.2, and 416.4 mm/min, which corresponded to welding speeds that an experienced welder considered to be “too slow,” “just right,” and “too fast” for the given test conditions.

Each of these samples was cut into three sections to observe the cross-section of the weld bead and the depth of penetration. The samples were prepared for measurement using the procedure described by the Welding Technology Institute of Australia (WTIA 2006). The surface of the cut section was ground for accurate measurements. For better visibility of the depth of penetration of the weld, Tucker’s reagent was applied to etch the ground surface. Tucker’s reagent consists of 10 ml of nitric acid, 25 ml of water, 45 ml of hydrochloric acid, and 15 ml of hydrofluoric acid (40%). The samples were then examined to determine the average height, width, and depth of the weld under the conditions specified. The experimental results were compared to the simulation results when using a grid size of 2 mm.

Results

The results from the sample welds are shown in Tables 1, 2, and 3. Table 1 refers to the weld bead height, Table 2 to the width, and Table 3 to the depth of penetration. The height, width, and depth are all given in mm, while the gun speed is given in mm/min.

In Tables 4, 5, and 6, the average results from the sample welds are compared to the results of the simulation. Table 4 shows the results for the height, Table 5 shows the results for width, and Table 6 shows the results for the depth of penetration. Height, weight, and depth are given in mm, while the gun speed is given in mm/min. When calculating the % error, the experimental values were taken as the true values when compared to the simulation.

Discussion of results

The overall average accuracy for height for all runs was 94.91%. For width, it was 92.39%, and for depth, it was 92.55%. This accuracy is sufficient for the purpose of a real-time interactive VR welding simulation. However, the data are indicative that the simulation is predicting that the weld is slightly “colder” than the real situation. If the plate being welded has not yet warmed up, such as when the welder first begins to weld, or if the voltage setting is too low for the material being used, the weld is said to be too “cold”, and as a result, the welding material tends to “pile up” on the surface of the plate, making the height of the weld bead too high and the width too narrow. This effect is especially notable at the two higher welding speeds of 199.2 and 416.4 mm/s. This is likely a result of the incomplete convergence of the numerical simulation between time steps, which tends to not distribute the heat in the direction of the weld quickly enough, especially at high welding speeds. A potential remedy would be to include one or two more iterations of the Gauss–Seidel method at each time step, but the simulation is already running near the capacity of the PC on which it is being run, so this is not a good solution at this time. As PCs inevitably get faster, this solution may become viable.

Another feature of the current simulation is the fact that the resolution of the numerical heat transfer grid is a comparatively coarse 2 mm. The expected simulation accuracy using this grid size cannot be expected to exceed the 90% range (which is what we observed). The reason for this is that the predicted parabolic shape of the weld bead above the plate (see Eq. 20) is a function of the width of the melt zone predicted by the heat transfer simulation. This width is approximately 10–14 mm. Thus, if the least count of the heat transfer simulation is 2 mm, then the average error between the simulated value and the true value will be on the order of 1 mm (assuming the simulation overestimates the value half of the time and underestimates half of the time). An average of 1-mm error out of a 10–14 mm width results in an anticipated error of 7–10% of the total width. This is what we observed experimentally, as shown in Table 5. Since the width drives the equation of the parabola that describes the shape of the weld bead, any errors in the width are propagated to the other dimensions of the simulated weld bead. This source of error could theoretically be reduced by reducing the grid size, but that would also increase the computational load, thus slowing down the simulation and creating problems with the real-time performance of the system. This issue is discussed in more detail below.

Real-time performance tests

Tests were performed to verify that the system would produce meaningful real-time results under the experimental conditions described in the Sample Welds section above. The experimental gun travel speeds were observed to be roughly in the range of 150–400 mm/min.

For the sMIG system, the numerical heat transfer simulation is run, then the system updates the visual display and the audio output, and then the simulation immediately runs again. The time elapsed between simulations is used along with prior gun positions to calculate the welding speed. As it turns out, most of the time is spent in the simulation and not updating the display. The refresh rate of the stereo display and the active glasses is 60 Hz, meaning that the display is updated every 16.7 ms. In the ideal case, the simulation would take no longer than 16.7 ms, so that updated information on the temperature distribution in the plate and the size and location of the weld bead could be sent to the display at every update opportunity. If the simulation runs too slowly and the welding speed is too high, the visual display may appear “spotty” and the bead may not appear to be continuous. This effect is shown in Fig. 6.

The amount of time required for the simulation depends primarily upon the number of nodes in the workpiece, which is a function of the plate dimensions and the density of the underlying grid. In order to validate real-time performance, an offline simulation was created that updates the current position based on a precompiled input speed, direction, and the fixed time step of 16.67 ms. This was then compared to a simulation using a variable time step based on the execution time of the simulation using the same velocity and direction.

The simulation was tested on a 2.16 GHz Core Duo with 2 GBs of RAM. For a mesh that contains 200,000 nodes, the simulation updates the current position every 84 ms, on average. A more accurate heat transfer simulation would result from a denser mesh, but that would also inevitably slow down the simulation and degrade the real-time visual effect. The second test was run on a plate with the same dimensions but twice the grid density, resulting in 1,600,000 nodes. The second simulation requires 1,762 ms to run. This execution time is far below real-time requirements.

Because the simulation time is dependent on the host hardware, the same tests were run again on a 2.6 Ghz Quad Core 2 Duo with 3 GBs of RAM. On that machine, the computation time is only 25 ms for a 200,000 node mesh and 200 ms for 1,600,000 nodes. The reduction in the simulation time for the denser grid from 1,762 to 200 ms is a significant improvement, but it is still twice the target threshold of the 100 ms. At this update rate, accurate visual depictions of the weld bead are hard to maintain, even for relatively slow welding speeds, as will be shown below.

Table 7 below shows the volumetric error in the weld bead for different welding speeds and simulation times for a fixed node count. The same information is also presented as a graph in Fig. 7.

As can be seen from Table 7, the simulation requires 84 ms to run with a grid size of 2 mm, and acceptable errors (of less than 10%) are obtained at welding speeds of up to approximately 1,000 mm/min, which is much faster than we would expect to ever need. On the other hand, when the simulation requires 200 ms to run, acceptable results would only be expected at welding speeds below 100 mm/s, which is probably too slow to be of practical use.

Recommendations for future work

There are several directions in which future work could proceed to improve the system. For instance, the grid size could automatically be optimized to give the best combination of fidelity in the heat transfer simulation vs. acceptable real-time performance for a given material, size of workpiece, and anticipated welding speed. In addition, experiments with non-uniform grid sizes in the vertical as opposed to the horizontal directions could be performed, as well as investigations with reduced computation volumes. Work has already begun to investigate the effect on the simulation of restricting the computation to a neighborhood of nodes surrounding the gun, rather than the entire plate.

Another possible solution to the speed limitations described above might be to move some of the computation for the simulation from the main processor to the processor on the graphics card.

This simulation has considered the welding speed, feed rate of wire, and the position of the welding gun as the input parameters. Another obvious improvement would be to include in the model the height of the welding gun from the surface of the workpiece and to calculate the temperature of the welding gun based on height and input voltage. In addition, future versions could include a table of materials with different material properties that would be automatically included in the simulation.

The technique described can easily be adapted to other metals besides aluminum simply by changing the material properties in the simulation. Since low carbon steel is the most common material joined by MIG welding operations, experiments are currently underway to validate the system for use with steel as well as aluminum.

The sMIG simulation technique could also be easily modified or extended to deal with other welding configurations, such as “T” or horizontal pipe welding, simply by modifying the shape of the grid. The equations would stay the same. However, vertical or inverted welds would require the addition of a gravity term that is not included in the present model.

Other means of providing feedback to the user could be investigated, including improved visual cues, improved audio feedback, and the use of haptics.

The final test of the utility of any VR training system will naturally be found in the results of user trials of the system. Plans are in place to study the use of the sMIG system as part of a welding class at a local community college in the near future. The results from these trials will be used to further improve the system.

Summary and conclusions

In summary, a numerical simulation has been created to simulate the temperature distribution in the plate and the shape of the weld bead, for use in a low-cost, real-time, interactive virtual reality simulated MIG welding training system, sMIG. When the simulation requires 84 ms to run, this allows the display to be updated nearly 12 times per second. This provides acceptable visual feedback and real-time performance for welding speeds up to 1,000 mm/min. This grid size also yields an overall accuracy of approximately 93% in terms of the size and shape of the weld bead compared to the experimental results, over the range of welding speeds tested from approximately 150 to 400 mm/min.
